You may want to switch to octopus for client side as well, e.g. here https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-helm-images/src/branch/master/zuul.d/openstack-loci.yaml#L380-L381
Also we use Mirantis ceph repos for all other releases. Mirantis Octopus repo, despite its naming, is publicly available and i would prefer it's used here as well.
Also please be careful changing FROM to base_image, it will break compatibility in external pipelines that pass this argument."}, {'account_id': 28372, 'date': '2021-01-05 19:55:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 8863, 'date': '2021-01-05 20:33:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Code-Review-1

commit_message:
[CEPH] Build Octopus based ceph images

This is to uplift ceph release from Nautilus to Octopus.

Change-Id: I36f54077be65741c0677d77cbbf4795db919703f

subject: Use keystone Session for neutron user client
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-12-18 01:39:02.000000000', 'message': 'Use keystone Session for neutron user client

Not using one has the side effect of skipping usage of various config
options for connections, including things like client certificate auth.

Change-Id: If75ab984313660e435d9820d9dc777e5bdd78546
'}]
commit_message:
Use keystone Session for neutron user client

Not using one has the side effect of skipping usage of various config
options for connections, including things like client certificate auth.

Change-Id: If75ab984313660e435d9820d9dc777e5bdd78546

commit_message:
un skip neutron tests for queens

Bug #1900357 is fixed now. Proper L3 agent extensions
are loaded in the neutron-l3-agent's config file and
that test should works fine.

Closes-Bug: #1900357

Change-Id: Ib738c65544ea997a3f0b3881609461b0a8725050
Signed-off-by: Chandan Kumar (raukadah) <chkumar@redhat.com>

subject: Use systemd sockets for libvirt
messages:
[{'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2020-11-18 16:58:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2020-11-18 16:58:59.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from bug/1903846 to listen_socket'}, {'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2020-11-18 17:00:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2020-11-19 08:41:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2021-01-06 11:09:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Published edit on patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2021-01-06 11:26:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Published edit on patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2021-01-06 11:44:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Workflow-1

I think this implementation should be made for all OS and we need to get CA cert for libvirt to listen on tls. So maybe we should wait for SSL topic to get done before merging this patch in any form. And until then just disable sockets approach for libvirt'}, {'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2021-01-06 12:30:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2021-01-06 15:27:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2021-01-06 15:32:46.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

in favor of 769556'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-11-18 16:58:41.000000000', 'message': "Use systemd sockets for libvirt

Since libvirt 5.7 you can't use traditional mode with systemd systems
by default. You need either to switch back to the traditional mode or
enable appropriate sockets. Since we want more control on the sockets
config (ie listen address or other options) we leverage our
systemd_service role to create alterantive systemd services to the
packaged ones.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/763211
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/763194
Change-Id: Ida1df164f50b93f470e5ab014b26fc5808e26e89
Closes-Bug: #1903846
"}, {'created': '2020-11-18 17:00:37.000000000', 'message': "Use systemd sockets for libvirt

Change-Id: Ida1df164f50b93f470e5ab014b26fc5808e26e89
Closes-Bug: #1903846
"}]
commit_message:
Use systemd sockets for libvirt

Since libvirt 5.7 you can't use traditional mode with systemd systems
by default. You need either to switch back to the traditional mode or
enable appropriate sockets. Since we want more control on the sockets
config (ie listen address or other options) we leverage our
systemd_service role to create alterantive systemd services to the
packaged ones.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/765815
Change-Id: Ida1df164f50b93f470e5ab014b26fc5808e26e89
Closes-Bug: #1903846

make them overridable which enables us to test "provisioning via

commit_message:
Allow to override extra_args & bm provisioning

We are adding extra_args & baremetal_provision to allowed_override to
make them overridable which enables us to test "provisioning via
metalsmith" feature in older branches and in downstream reusing fs001
and not maintain an entirely new featureset for these few settings.

baremetal_provision allows provisioning of node using metalsmith
workflow instead of heat/nova, This is true by default for ussuri+
branches.[1]

Also, we need to pass --disable-validations in deployment command when
we provision nodes via metalsmith which is set by default in
ussuri+[2]. This can be set using extra_args.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart/src/branch/master/config/general_config/featureset001.yml#L231-L236
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart/src/branch/master/config/general_config/featureset001.yml#L72-L78
Change-Id: Ied37aa4ed8592142704446d20a3665345e46bddc

Change-Id: Ib90d5c064d6b22e027f2a6f26bb84bcb021b702a

commit_message:
Make the debian job voting and start publishing debian images

With only 270MiB in size, the Debian images are likely candidates
for our future default images. Given that CentOS Stream 8 images
are nearly 500MiB in size, Debian may be our only path forward.

Enable installing firmware on Debian images to make them suitable
for bare metal installations.

Do not try to install biosdevname on non-RH systems.

Change-Id: I2c2a71c4afd0cd534961317b7fe9d3fb5d007d24

In the "/v3/auth/project" API, the "identity:get_auth_projects" rule has
been used to check permissions. In the similar "/v3/auth/domains" API,
the "identity:get_auth_domains" rule has been used to check.

Unused rules "identity:list_projects_for_user" and

'}]
commit_message:
Remove unused policy rule

In the "/v3/auth/project" API, the "identity:get_auth_projects" rule has
been used to check permissions. In the similar "/v3/auth/domains" API,
the "identity:get_auth_domains" rule has been used to check.

Unused rules "identity:list_projects_for_user" and
"identity:list_domains_for_user" should be removed.

Change-Id: Icd3a00d9a78f1516a0080f065679aa59ac699a98

[{'created': '2021-01-05 03:16:03.000000000', 'message': "Ensure cinder LVM volumes work after system restart

Update the cinder-lvm-losetup systemd service to wait until the local
/var directory is mounted and the lvm2-monitor service has started
prior to creating the loopback device used by cinder's LVM backend.

Make LIO SCSI target data persistent by adding container volume mounts
for the /etc/target directory so that the data is stored on the host.

NOTE(stable/train): The setype for persistent directories is set to
svirt_sandbox_file_t, whereas later releases use container_file_t.

Closes-Bug: #1905617
Change-Id: I0c0cbed3a41e8d4b1fbaf5c2dc7fd0412fee644a
(cherry picked from commit 63b2a989ba4a79c204c6d2a4b1512e3a924ec434)
(cherry picked from commit 27678af1ab36ac531b8dd694ca92a461df43ec7b)
(cherry picked from commit 833e812bafd8e34919e301537ca655826e393e74)
"}]
commit_message:
Ensure cinder LVM volumes work after system restart

Update the cinder-lvm-losetup systemd service to wait until the local
/var directory is mounted and the lvm2-monitor service has started
prior to creating the loopback device used by cinder's LVM backend.

Make LIO SCSI target data persistent by adding container volume mounts
for the /etc/target directory so that the data is stored on the host.

NOTE(stable/train): The setype for persistent directories is set to
svirt_sandbox_file_t, whereas later releases use container_file_t.

Closes-Bug: #1905617
Change-Id: I0c0cbed3a41e8d4b1fbaf5c2dc7fd0412fee644a
(cherry picked from commit 63b2a989ba4a79c204c6d2a4b1512e3a924ec434)
(cherry picked from commit 27678af1ab36ac531b8dd694ca92a461df43ec7b)
(cherry picked from commit 833e812bafd8e34919e301537ca655826e393e74)

subject: Support upgrades to Trilio 4.1
messages: [{'account_id': 12549, 'date': '2020-12-17 11:49:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 12549, 'date': '2020-12-17 11:58:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 935, 'date': '2021-01-06 11:11:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 12549, 'date': '2021-01-06 13:43:58.000000000', 'content': 'Created a revert of this change as I5a4b8f8602c2a46b340765a8a22fdc218560dfc6'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-12-17 11:49:25.000000000', 'message': 'Support trilio upgrades

Change-Id: I5a5e5721d9a713b66f8c796896c400481e9733a2
'}, {'created': '2020-12-17 11:58:28.000000000', 'message': 'Support upgrades to Trilio 4.1

Adding support for Trilio 4.1 includes the following changes:

* Add Trilio_properties config property to enables templates to distinguish
  between 4.0 and 4.1 release.
* Add get_trilio_codename_install_source to attempt to derive the Trilio
  version supported by an apt repo.
* Add get_trilio_charm_instance which overrides the default get_charm_instance.
  This will pick the correct charm class based on both the Trilio release and
  the OpenStack release.
* Add select_trilio_release which overrides the default select_release and
  calculates the target OpenStack and Trilio release.
* Add a specialist Trilio metaclass BaseTrilioCharmMeta. This registers
  charm classes using their OpenStack release, Trilio release and package
  type.
* Move code shared between TrilioVaultCharm & TrilioVaultSubordinateCharm
  to TrilioVaultCharmMixin. Add support for Trilio upgrades to
  TrilioVaultCharmMixina.

Change-Id: I5a5e5721d9a713b66f8c796896c400481e9733a2
'}]
commit_message:
Support upgrades to Trilio 4.1

Adding support for Trilio 4.1 includes the following changes:

* Add Trilio_properties config property to enables templates to distinguish
  between 4.0 and 4.1 release.
* Add get_trilio_codename_install_source to attempt to derive the Trilio
  version supported by an apt repo.
* Add get_trilio_charm_instance which overrides the default get_charm_instance.
  This will pick the correct charm class based on both the Trilio release and
  the OpenStack release.
* Add select_trilio_release which overrides the default select_release and
  calculates the target OpenStack and Trilio release.
* Add a specialist Trilio metaclass BaseTrilioCharmMeta. This registers
  charm classes using their OpenStack release, Trilio release and package
  type.
* Move code shared between TrilioVaultCharm & TrilioVaultSubordinateCharm
  to TrilioVaultCharmMixin. Add support for Trilio upgrades to
  TrilioVaultCharmMixina.

Change-Id: I5a5e5721d9a713b66f8c796896c400481e9733a2

Fix docs requirements for new pip

Docs requirements could fail because of
using test-requirements instead of doc/requirements
as announced on openstack list[1]. This commit
avoids that by creating a doc/requirements.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-January/019611.html

Change-Id: I2ee7ff82855e7e528808ecbb60fee598b740d83c

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-01-05 13:08:05.000000000', 'message': "Add doc/requirements

We need to specify doc requirements in doc/requirements.txt
to avoid problems with the pip resolver [1] for the release team [2][3].
Removed specific doc requirements from test-requirements.txt.

The problem here is that this repos haven't doc/requirements.txt file
and by default in this case zuul will use the test-requirements.txt file
to pull requirements [4].

This requirements file contains extra requirements like flake8 that
collided with those allowed in our job environment and so the new pip
resolver fails to install these requirements and the job exits in error.

This project meet the conditions leading to the bug however it doesn't
produce any doc or releasenotes, but uniformization can't hurt and help
us in the future.

/!\/!\/!\
Notice that I voluntarily added the doc directory even if no docs
are generated here because zuul will try to pull this requirements from
there first and the contained requirements are needed for reno but AFAIK
the releasenotes dir is ignored by zuul. c.f [4] for further details.
/!\/!\/!\

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/release-job-failures/2021-January/001500.html
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-January/019611.html
[3] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-January/019612.html
[4] https://opendev.org/zuul/zuul-jobs/src/branch/master/roles/ensure-sphinx/tasks/main.yaml#L36

Change-Id: I18fdf133b6c3ea9b60e784c0e1dfb7ce1217eda5

commit_message:
Add doc/requirements

We need to specify doc requirements in doc/requirements.txt
to avoid problems with the pip resolver [1] for the release team [2][3].
Removed specific doc requirements from test-requirements.txt.

The problem here is that this repos haven't doc/requirements.txt file
and by default in this case zuul will use the test-requirements.txt file
to pull requirements [4].

This requirements file contains extra requirements like flake8 that
collided with those allowed in our job environment and so the new pip
resolver fails to install these requirements and the job exits in error.

This project meet the conditions leading to the bug however it doesn't
produce any doc or releasenotes, but uniformization can't hurt and help
us in the future.

/!\/!\/!\
Notice that I voluntarily added the doc directory even if no docs
are generated here because zuul will try to pull this requirements from
there first and the contained requirements are needed for reno but AFAIK
the releasenotes dir is ignored by zuul. c.f [4] for further details.
/!\/!\/!\

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/release-job-failures/2021-January/001500.html
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-January/019611.html
[3] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-January/019612.html
[4] https://opendev.org/zuul/zuul-jobs/src/branch/master/roles/ensure-sphinx/tasks/main.yaml#L36

Change-Id: I18fdf133b6c3ea9b60e784c0e1dfb7ce1217eda5

commit_message:
[WIP] Test --reverse-zone

The inclusion of --auto-reverse in the IPA server
deploy command is causing errors on certains clouds where
the zone being created already exists and is owned by
some other dns server.

we tried removal of --auto-reverse but because of this removal the reverse DNS lookup
won't work properly and undercloud install failed on TASK [Enroll to FreeIPA]
with below error:-

Change-Id: I62768e9eaa9c2d483d5784a6e48d5346e56fb67e

[{'created': '2020-12-23 19:22:00.000000000', 'message': "Add distribute_private_key boolean for tripleo_create_admin

Add boolean option to distribute the private key which is
created by the cli-enable-ssh-admin.yaml playbook and update
the tripleo_create_admin role to distribute the private key
when it is true.

This option defaults to false as we normally don't want to
do this. However, cephadm needs a private key on all nodes
with the OS::TripleO::Services::CephMgr service in order to
manage a Ceph cluster. This option will likely only be used
for the ceph-admin user which is similar to but not the same
as the tripleo-admin user.

Also, remove old reference to Mistral in task name.

Implements: blueprint tripleo-ceph
Change-Id: I69c74c1869aa0f54c1695fd53098df7e78f64247
"}, {'created': '2020-12-23 20:13:44.000000000', 'message': "Add distribute_private_key boolean for tripleo_create_admin

when it is true.

This option defaults to false as we normally don't want to

with the OS::TripleO::Services::CephMgr service in order to
manage a Ceph cluster. This option will likely only be used

as the tripleo-admin user.

Also, remove old reference to Mistral in task name.

Change-Id: I69c74c1869aa0f54c1695fd53098df7e78f64247
"}]
commit_message:
Add distribute_private_key boolean for tripleo_create_admin

Add boolean option to distribute the private key which is
created by the cli-enable-ssh-admin.yaml playbook and update
the tripleo_create_admin role to distribute the private key
when it is true.

This option defaults to false as we normally don't want to
do this. However, cephadm needs a private key on all nodes
with the OS::TripleO::Services::CephMgr service in order to
manage a Ceph cluster. This option will likely only be used
for the ceph-admin user which is similar to but not the same
as the tripleo-admin user.

Also, remove old reference to Mistral in task name.

Implements: blueprint tripleo-ceph
Change-Id: I69c74c1869aa0f54c1695fd53098df7e78f64247

Add doc/requirements

We need to specify doc requirements in doc/requirements.txt
to avoid problems with the pip resolver [1] for the release team [2][3].
Removed specific doc requirements from test-requirements.txt.
The problem here is that this repos haven't doc/requirements.txt file
and by default in this case zuul will use the test-requirements.txt file
to pull requirements [4].

This requirements file contains extra requirements like flake8 that
collided with those allowed in our job environment and so the new pip
resolver fails to install these requirements and the job exits in error.

This project meet the conditions leading to the bug.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/release-job-failures/2021-January/001500.html
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-January/019611.html
[3] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-January/019612.html
[4] https://opendev.org/zuul/zuul-jobs/src/branch/master/roles/ensure-sphinx/tasks/main.yaml#L36

Change-Id: Ia9616b9c14d59ff382509086fcbf00f56a0701ea

commit_message:
Add 'networks_all' ansible group_var

Add a group_var carrying all enabled overcloud
networks. The multi-nic templates should iterate
over all the networks in the order they apper in
network_data.yaml to allow maintaining the
network to nicX contract that existed in the Heat
mulit-nic config templates.

Change-Id: I69fa208d160f1ae2cb2cc252d9b7852ada9e96f0
Related-Bug: #1904894
(cherry picked from commit fe275dd918169eb6090da0cf4a9a2c17da3227c7)

commit_message:
[Validator Show Run] Display simplified results by default

This patch is displaying the content of the validation_output dictionary
which is a simplified output content (the former validation_output)
instead of dumping the entire log file in the stdout.

It also fixes the --full argument which was True forever!

Change-Id: Id94132d23d272d383b65a839a75b08f855fb6be3
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud (Strider) <gchamoul@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 4229bee94016ad5a78dd8455f282a8e7f4a3d28e)

commit_message:
Add doc/requirements

We need to specify doc requirements in doc/requirements.txt
to avoid problems with the pip resolver [1] for the release team [2][3].
Removed specific doc requirements from test-requirements.txt.

The problem here is that this repos haven't doc/requirements.txt file
and by default in this case zuul will use the test-requirements.txt file
to pull requirements [4].

This requirements file contains extra requirements like flake8 that
collided with those allowed in our job environment and so the new pip
resolver fails to install these requirements and the job exits in error.

This project meet the conditions leading to the bug.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/release-job-failures/2021-January/001500.html
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-January/019611.html
[3] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-January/019612.html
[4] https://opendev.org/zuul/zuul-jobs/src/branch/master/roles/ensure-sphinx/tasks/main.yaml#L36

Change-Id: I6bdfa9830a32ecf36e1931e1bb0afa366f1dfeb9

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-12-03 18:12:39.000000000', 'message': "compute: Add missing options for 'server rebuild'

This accepts a large number of options that we weren't exposing. Add the
following options: '--name', '--preserve-ephemeral', '--user-data',
'--no-user-data', '--trusted-image-cert' and '--no-trusted-image-certs'.
In addition, rename the '--key-unset' parameter to '--no-key-name', to

commit_message:
compute: Add missing options for 'server rebuild'

This accepts a large number of options that we weren't exposing. Add the
following options: '--name', '--preserve-ephemeral', '--user-data',
'--no-user-data', '--trusted-image-cert' and '--no-trusted-image-certs'.
In addition, rename the '--key-unset' parameter to '--no-key-name', to
mimic e.g. '--no-property' on other commands.

Change-Id: I61c46e18bef1f086b62a015ebdc56be91071b826
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Add Victoria version installation for Ubuntu 20.04

As the official Ubuntu wiki[1], victoria cloud-archive is available
for Ubuntu 20.04LTS and the wiki shows how to use it.
In addition, I confirmed it works locally.
This adds the description for the installation guide.

[1]: https://wiki.ubuntu.com/OpenStack/CloudArchive

Change-Id: I2c1d22274436c5902145c60de2fec9146f313c43

commit_message:
Add 'flavor list --min-disk', '--min-ram' options

Allow us to filter on minimum disk and RAM, and close another gap with
novaclient.

Change-Id: Ib3f0bdf419675e1c35c3406fbac8a4c18ac56a33
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Fix libvirt permissions for snapshots

Ensure that the libvirt-qemu user is a member of the nova group,
supporting access to snapshots managed by TrilioVault.

Change-Id: I11d7a35c83f7689a1eb6c897b21a6f1bb866a525
Closes-Bug: 1888389

[{'account_id': 30095, 'date': '2020-12-03 05:40:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 30095, 'date': '2020-12-03 05:41:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

Need to test whether the default empty value will overwrite the prefix for environment deployed when this param was not available yet.'}, {'account_id': 30095, 'date': '2020-12-03 05:41:58.000000000', 'content': 'Set Work In Progress'}, {'account_id': 16515, 'date': '2020-12-03 08:41:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 30095, 'date': '2020-12-03 10:17:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

This change is ready for review.'}, {'account_id': 16515, 'date': '2020-12-03 10:20:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 30095, 'date': '2020-12-03 12:44:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 16515, 'date': '2020-12-03 12:47:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 30095, 'date': '2020-12-03 13:00:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

(1 comment)

Fixed the commit message.

I'll remove my Workflow -1 as soon as I test this new parameter in a already deployed env that had swift_hash_path_prefix set manually. I'm worried that using this template without explicitly setting any SwiftHashPrefix, might make all swift data irretrievable.

(Unless any of you can confirm this is not the case)"}, {'account_id': 30095, 'date': '2020-12-03 13:22:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 30095, 'date': '2020-12-03 13:22:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 30095, 'date': '2020-12-03 13:41:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 30095, 'date': '2020-12-03 13:42:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 30095, 'date': '2020-12-04 09:44:23.000000000', 'content': 'Set Work In Progress'}, {'account_id': 30095, 'date': '2020-12-05 16:28:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

I was only able to test this patch in a Queens POC, with this patch manually applied on it.

Result: No side effects detected. 

In an environment deployed with env file (1), I could not see the prefix being accidentally reverted to an empty string if no SwiftHashPrefix was passed on deploy.

(1)
~~~

 parameter_defaults:
   ControllerExtraConfig:
     swift::swift_hash_path_prefix: secret-prefix
~~~

I've deployed multiple times, with different patterns, but I can confirm that:

(for each controller node)

- manually cleaning up swift_hash_path_prefix from /var/lib/config-data/puppet-generated/swift/etc/swift/swift.conf
- deleting /etc/puppet/hieradata/controller_extraconfig.json
- issuing multiple consecutive deployments using env file (2)
(2)
~~~
parameter_defaults:

    SwiftHashPrefix: new-prefix-through-tht-param
~~~
still resulted in the original prefix being used.

The same results was achieved when deploying without including (1) and (2), or when including only (1).

This is how the controller looked after deploying using (2)
~~~
[heat-admin@controller-0 ~]$ sudo -i
[root@controller-0 ~]# cat /var/lib/config-data/puppet-generated/swift/etc/swift/swift.conf 
[swift-hash]
swift_hash_path_suffix = xxx
swift_hash_path_prefix=secret-prefix

[swift-constraints]
max_header_size=8192

[root@controller-1 ~]# grep -ir prefix /etc/puppet/hieradata/
/etc/puppet/hieradata/service_configs.json:    "gnocchi::storage::s3::s3_bucket_prefix": "",
/etc/puppet/hieradata/service_configs.json:    "swift::swift_hash_path_prefix": "new-prefix-through-tht-param", <====
/etc/puppet/hieradata/service_configs.json:    "tripleo::profile::base::swift::ringbuilder::raw_disk_prefix": "r1z1-",
/etc/puppet/hieradata/controller_extraconfig.json:    "swift::swift_hash_path_prefix": "secret-prefix" <=====
~~~


Being said that, in this exact environment I was not able to actually override the original prefix using (2).

I'll test again in an environment that has no swift_hash_path_prefix set through (1), and confirm that swift_hash_path_prefix is properly set to the value of SwiftHashPrefix.'}, {'account_id': 30095, 'date': '2020-12-08 08:51:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: -Workflow

(1 comment)

I've confirmed all the following the patterns work as intended:

- Deploy using (1)

1) re-deploy without using (1) -> existing prefix is not changed, as expected
2) re-deploy using (2) without (1) -> existing prefix is not changed, as expected
3) re-deploy using (3) -> existing prefix is changed, as expected

I believe this is good to be reviewed now!

(1)
~~~
 parameter_defaults:
   ControllerExtraConfig:
     swift::swift_hash_path_prefix: secret-prefix
~~~

(2)
~~~
parameter_defaults:
    SwiftHashPrefix: new-prefix-through-tht-param
~~~

(3)
~~~
parameter_defaults:
    ControllerExtraConfig: {} # this removes the Heat parameter set by (1)
    SwiftHashPrefix: new-prefix-through-tht-param
~~~"}, {'account_id': 30073, 'date': '2020-12-09 08:14:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

Looks good. The test scenarios Michele mention seem to demonstrate that this should be a safe change for people already using the option via ExtraConfig prior to this change merging.'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2020-12-09 13:57:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 30095, 'date': '2020-12-10 00:26:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 30095, 'date': '2020-12-14 00:41:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

check-rdo'}, {'account_id': 30095, 'date': '2020-12-14 14:11:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

commit_message:
Add SwiftHashPrefix parameter

Adds a new parameter 'SwiftHashPrefix' to allow swift
to have its hash_prefix parameter set.

Story: 2008411
Related-RHBZ: #1903901

commit_message:
Adding key_size option on the certificate creation

Adding the ability to specifies the private key size
used when creating the certificate. We have defined the
default value the same as we have before 2048 bits.
Also, it'll be able to override the key_size value
per service.

Depends-on: I4da96f2164cf1d136f9471f1d6251bdd8cfd2d0b
Change-Id: Ic2edabb7f1bd0caf4a5550d03f60fab7c8354d65

commit_message:
Adding key_size option on the certmonger_certificate function

certmonger_certificate function currently does not support
creating certificates with private keys stronger than 2048bits.
Adding a key_size option.

key_size option were added on puppet_certmonger on the v2.6.0
upstream: https://github.com/saltedsignal/puppet-certmonger/releases/tag/v2.6.0

Change-Id: I4da96f2164cf1d136f9471f1d6251bdd8cfd2d0b
(cherry picked from commit 190aebca609e8ec68586cfa4ced9f2efa65758d1)

add a static one for the ethernet interface too for completeness.

commit_message:
Adding key_size option on the certmonger_certificate function

certmonger_certificate function currently does not support
creating certificates with private keys stronger than 2048bits.

commit_message:
Adding key_size option on the certmonger_certificate function

certmonger_certificate function currently does not support
creating certificates with private keys stronger than 2048bits.
Adding a key_size option.

key_size option were added on puppet_certmonger on the v2.6.0
upstream: https://github.com/saltedsignal/puppet-certmonger/releases/tag/v2.6.0

Change-Id: I4da96f2164cf1d136f9471f1d6251bdd8cfd2d0b
(cherry picked from commit 190aebca609e8ec68586cfa4ced9f2efa65758d1)

[{'created': '2020-12-01 21:07:52.000000000', 'message': 'Identify HSMs using labels instead of Slot ID

This patch adds support for two new options in barbican.conf for the
PKCS#11 backend plugin:  [p11_crypto]token_label and
[p11_crypto]token_serial_number by adding two new parameters
to the Barbican deployment BarbicanPkcs11CryptoTokenSerialNumber
and BarbicanPkcs11CryptoTokenLabel.

This patch also simplifies the use of barbican-manage to generate
the MKEK and PKEK in the HSM backend by using the values provided
in barbican.conf instead of duplicating them on the command line.

For the Thales Luna Network device, this patch uses the label
parameters to identify the partition to be used.  Because we are
using labels we no longer need to write the runtime generated
Slot ID of the HA group into hieradata.

commit_message:
Identify HSMs using labels instead of Slot ID

This patch adds support for two new options in barbican.conf for the
PKCS#11 backend plugin:  [p11_crypto]token_label and
[p11_crypto]token_serial_number by adding two new parameters
to the Barbican deployment BarbicanPkcs11CryptoTokenSerialNumber
and BarbicanPkcs11CryptoTokenLabel.

This patch also simplifies the use of barbican-manage to generate
the MKEK and PKEK in the HSM backend by using the values provided
in barbican.conf instead of duplicating them on the command line.

For the Thales Luna Network device, this patch uses the label
parameters to identify the partition to be used.  Because we are
using labels we no longer need to write the runtime generated
Slot ID of the HA group into hieradata.

Depends-On: I4e86e73bbdef0e16d3699cec1cc8f7e17dfb643b
Change-Id: Id05acb6516daa62279c9aade41256bcec7c5fce7
(cherry picked from commit 04b4ec3866446df45dab628782702cd1444c3575)

commit_message:
Identify HSMs using labels instead of Slot ID

This patch adds support for two new options in barbican.conf for the
PKCS#11 backend plugin:  [p11_crypto]token_label and
[p11_crypto]token_serial_number by adding two new parameters
to the Barbican deployment BarbicanPkcs11CryptoTokenSerialNumber
and BarbicanPkcs11CryptoTokenLabel.

This patch also simplifies the use of barbican-manage to generate
the MKEK and PKEK in the HSM backend by using the values provided
in barbican.conf instead of duplicating them on the command line.

For the Thales Luna Network device, this patch uses the label
parameters to identify the partition to be used.  Because we are
using labels we no longer need to write the runtime generated
Slot ID of the HA group into hieradata.

Depends-On: I4e86e73bbdef0e16d3699cec1cc8f7e17dfb643b
Change-Id: Id05acb6516daa62279c9aade41256bcec7c5fce7
(cherry picked from commit 04b4ec3866446df45dab628782702cd1444c3575)

messages: [{'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2021-01-05 10:36:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 15197, 'date': '2021-01-05 22:24:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 15197, 'date': '2021-01-06 08:47:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-01-05 10:36:49.000000000', 'message': "Add doc/requirements

We need to specify doc requirements in doc/requirements.txt
to avoid problems with the pip resolver [1] for the release team [2][3].
Removed specific doc requirements from test-requirements.txt.

The problem here is that this repos haven't doc/requirements.txt file
and by default in this case zuul will use the test-requirements.txt file
to pull requirements [4].

This requirements file contains extra requirements like flake8 that
collided with those allowed in our job environment and so the new pip
resolver fails to install these requirements and the job exits in error.

This project meet the conditions leading to the bug.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/release-job-failures/2021-January/001500.html
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-January/019611.html

commit_message:
Add doc/requirements

We need to specify doc requirements in doc/requirements.txt
to avoid problems with the pip resolver [1] for the release team [2][3].
Removed specific doc requirements from test-requirements.txt.

The problem here is that this repos haven't doc/requirements.txt file
and by default in this case zuul will use the test-requirements.txt file
to pull requirements [4].

This requirements file contains extra requirements like flake8 that
collided with those allowed in our job environment and so the new pip
resolver fails to install these requirements and the job exits in error.

This project meet the conditions leading to the bug.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/release-job-failures/2021-January/001500.html
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-January/019611.html
[3] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-January/019612.html
[4] https://opendev.org/zuul/zuul-jobs/src/branch/master/roles/ensure-sphinx/tasks/main.yaml#L36

Change-Id: I23bbefb2549afdb7e54c9b0c245a338cae4e81e9

New test case: "test_remove_security_group_negative"

Expected result: "404 NotFound" Error for both cases.
Polarion IDs: RHOSP7-3461, RHOSP7-3460

[{'account_id': 28609, 'date': '2020-11-09 13:21:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 28609, 'date': '2020-11-09 20:29:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 19118, 'date': '2020-11-10 08:25:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 19118, 'date': '2020-11-10 08:49:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 11075, 'date': '2020-11-10 09:31:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

Hi All, 
To be honest, I don't like the naming here: TestMinimumBasicScenario 
This class should be refactored with naming and purpose.

As for the reboot:  this class is a duplication of others and the only new here is the reboot in the scenario. I will vote to create scenario like "nova_reboot_when_vol_attached... " or something


This class should use existing code from manager.py and not duplicating stuff.

My -1 is not for your code but for the class and we should not continue to add when the whole class should be refactored.'}, {'account_id': 28609, 'date': '2020-11-10 10:27:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Benny - the class name you don't like and the fact that this class is already exists where it is, are just saying to me that such a merge have been approved in the past by Tempest cores and folks, so maybe it's a bit late to raise it now.

My patch is about test coverage improvement for already existing test only.

I think that nothing will happen if this patch will be merged without code refactoring. If you think that refactoring is must it can be done in the future as planned improvements/enhancement/RFE... once other Tempest folks agree with you.

Unfortunately my experience and skills working with Tempest are not enough for making such code changes :("}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2020-11-10 10:39:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 28609, 'date': '2020-11-10 11:09:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Some comments in line'}, {'account_id': 5689, 'date': '2020-11-10 12:58:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

And, basically, we can refactor the code before/after improving the coverage if it's needed."}, {'account_id': 28609, 'date': '2020-11-10 14:07:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 28609, 'date': '2020-11-11 04:35:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 28609, 'date': '2020-11-12 09:41:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2020-11-20 12:29:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Long time ago we decided not to care about soft or hard reboot type.
The nova `soft reboot` in case the VM not reposing in time switches to HARD reboot anyway.

SOFT reboot may send an ACPI request to the VM, 
but it is difficult to check under load and in case if we want to support multiple guest image and `soft` notification request it might be tricky to do. 

Per one of the old discussion we might have removed (or at least it was planned) to remove one type of reboot test from several places.

In scenario case, just passing a different parameter to a reboot,
just leads to more CI time, with close to zero coverage benefit .

Last time we checked the nova API was not able to tell which reboot happened either, so we do not know whenever the soft become hard ..'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2020-11-21 19:09:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

As afazekas mentioned, we cannot verify the reboot by API if that is soft or hard. We have removed the soft reboot test in https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tempest/+/647718'}, {'account_id': 28609, 'date': '2020-11-21 20:57:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

As far as I see the only tested type we are currently have in Tempest is SOFT:
https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/9ca8827ff52bf1a94a860ac5503702ad059ca18d/tempest/scenario/test_minimum_basic.py#L71

How can we know if HARD type is actually works? I mean maybe (in some OSP version) the API responsible to reboot the VM responds with "Bad request" when "HARD" type is received, is that covered somewhere?


My suggestion would be:

Adding "HARD" type reboot without having SSH connectivity check after VM is up again.
From what I've seen on my OSP 16 setup, the time needed for SSH check is about ~4 minutes after ~22 attempts (I don't know why, nothing in logs) but it's too much I think. Such a change will increase the total test execution time, but for sure not drastically. Disk validation will remain the same and will be done for for both types: HARD and SOFT.

Adding "slow" decorator, seems to me that this decorator is must here as this test is really slow. 
For example 247.11 for my patch:

https://storage.bhs.cloud.ovh.net/v1/AUTH_dcaab5e32b234d56b626f72581e3644c/zuul_opendev_logs_ef0/761917/3/check/tempest-full-parallel/ef024bf/job-output.txt
2020-11-12 12:31:32.575728 | controller | {3} tempest.scenario.test_minimum_basic.TestMinimumBasicScenario.test_minimum_basic_scenario [247.119631s] ... ok

The above means that the SOFT only could take ~120[sec], so 2 minutes sounds like "slow" decorator could be in place here, but maybe I'm wrong.'}, {'account_id': 28609, 'date': '2020-11-29 11:37:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2020-12-01 20:11:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

> Patch Set 3:
> 
> As far as I see the only tested type we are currently have in Tempest is SOFT:
> https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/9ca8827ff52bf1a94a860ac5503702ad059ca18d/tempest/scenario/test_minimum_basic.py#L71
> 
> How can we know if HARD type is actually works? I mean maybe (in some OSP version) the API responsible to reboot the VM responds with "Bad request" when "HARD" type is received, is that covered somewhere?
> 
> 
> My suggestion would be:
> 
> Adding "HARD" type reboot without having SSH connectivity check after VM is up again.
> From what I've seen on my OSP 16 setup, the time needed for SSH check is about ~4 minutes after ~22 attempts (I don't know why, nothing in logs) but it's too much I think. Such a change will increase the total test execution time, but for sure not drastically. Disk validation will remain the same and will be done for for both types: HARD and SOFT.
> 
> Adding "slow" decorator, seems to me that this decorator is must here as this test is really slow. 
> For example 247.11 for my patch:
> 
> https://storage.bhs.cloud.ovh.net/v1/AUTH_dcaab5e32b234d56b626f72581e3644c/zuul_opendev_logs_ef0/761917/3/check/tempest-full-parallel/ef024bf/job-output.txt
> 2020-11-12 12:31:32.575728 | controller | {3} tempest.scenario.test_minimum_basic.TestMinimumBasicScenario.test_minimum_basic_scenario [247.119631s] ... ok
> 
> The above means that the SOFT only could take ~120[sec], so 2 minutes sounds like "slow" decorator could be in place here, but maybe I'm wrong.

The challenge from tempest side for HARD reboot is nova does not fail if it is not able to perform the hard reboot and fallback to soft reboot. and API does note tell if hard reboot you requested is performed or not. That is why it makes difficult to cover this operation coverage in Tempest. If we have some mechanism from API side or from guest server to know if hard reboot is performed or not then we can add test.'}, {'account_id': 28609, 'date': '2020-12-01 21:10:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Does it mean that we have some useless option in Openstack to reboot the VM (I mean reboot type, both of them: SOFT and HARD)?
If we cannot guarantee administrators that activated type was activated, then why do we need it at all? 
Why not adding some indication into the API response body to indicate which type was actually activated? I can open RFE/enhancement if you find it relevant.


As for this patch I have 3 options out of my mind:

1) HARD type is the same as SHUT DOWN followed by TURN ON the VM, see "Hard Reboot" section:
https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-us/red_hat_openstack_platform/9/html/instances_and_images_guide/ch-manage_instances 
I can do that in test when "HARD" type is used. 
The question is will it be accepted by folks?

2) To add "slow decorator" only to the existing test.
Without any "HARD" reboot related changes I did. (Only if you find it relevant)

3) To abandon this patch.

Please let me know what do you think, I'm OK with all options mentioned above.'}, {'account_id': 28609, 'date': '2020-12-02 14:24:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2021-01-05 15:17:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

For me this looks ok but I'm not neighter Nova nor Tempest expert so ... :)"}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2021-01-05 20:03:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

> Patch Set 4:
> 
> Does it mean that we have some useless option in Openstack to reboot the VM (I mean reboot type, both of them: SOFT and HARD)?
> If we cannot guarantee administrators that activated type was activated, then why do we need it at all? 
> Why not adding some indication into the API response body to indicate which type was actually activated? I can open RFE/enhancement if you find it relevant.
> 
> 
> As for this patch I have 3 options out of my mind:
> 
> 1) HARD type is the same as SHUT DOWN followed by TURN ON the VM, see "Hard Reboot" section:
> https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-us/red_hat_openstack_platform/9/html/instances_and_images_guide/ch-manage_instances 
> I can do that in test when "HARD" type is used. 
> The question is will it be accepted by folks?
> 
> 2) To add "slow decorator" only to the existing test.
> Without any "HARD" reboot related changes I did. (Only if you find it relevant)
> 
> 3) To abandon this patch.
> 
> Please let me know what do you think, I'm OK with all options mentioned above.


> Does it mean that we have some useless option in Openstack to reboot the VM (I mean reboot type, both of them: SOFT and HARD)?

This is not useless, these two operation has their own use case.
Soft reboot: is graceful shutdown where event goes to the operating system which try to close all running application first and then reboot.
Hard reboot: is nothing but same as pulling the power cable or power button of your physical server.

 For example, as admin I would first try the soft reboot which is what every user do for their VM/personal desktop/laptop and wait for machine/VM to get back to power on state. If that does not work then yes we pull out the power cable or power button which has to be successful otherwise my machine/VM is gone.

> 1) HARD type is the same as SHUT DOWN followed by TURN ON the VM, see "Hard Reboot" section:
> https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-us/red_hat_openstack_platform/9/html/instances_and_images_guide/ch-manage_instances 

Well, shutdown definition is not so clear in that doc. As mentioned above, soft reboot is shutdown event to operating system and hard reboot is just same as pulling power cable.
- https://docs.openstack.org/api-guide/compute/server_concepts.html#server-actions


> Why not adding some indication into the API response body to indicate which type was actually activated? I can open RFE/enhancement if you find it relevant.

With my nova hats on.
Depends on which hypervisor driver you have configured in your cloud, Nova try to do soft reboot if requested and if soft reboot is not successful, it fallback to hard reboot without asking input from user.

Users are not notified on what reboot is successful, or API does not fail if soft reboot is requested and fail but hard reboot is successful. In nova code, VM task state is only thing are differencing for soft reboot it will be like REBOOTING, REBOOT_STARTED etc and in hard reboot case it will be  REBOOTING_HARD, REBOOT_STARTED_HARD. If admin want to know which reboot is tried then task state can be checked in nova log.

Whether if returning final tried reboot type via API help or not that we can discuss in Nova channel or via nova spec. if nova API return it then we can test in Tempest. Until then there is no way for Tempest to test these two reboot type differently. 

For example, 
libvirt: https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/34c5df7b2b8c7eebbfc8aa0bc3edba501dddcb61/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py#L3188
Ironic: https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/34c5df7b2b8c7eebbfc8aa0bc3edba501dddcb61/nova/virt/ironic/driver.py#L1409'}, {'account_id': 28609, 'date': '2021-01-06 09:21:38.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Not relevant test for Tempest'}]

commit_message:
Adding 'HARD' type reboot into "test_minimum_basic_scenario"

It's important to chech SSH and Disk access after VM reboot
There are two types to reboot VM: SOFT and HARD (power off)
and reboot test scenario needs to cover both types.
The original test contains SOFT type only.

Change-Id: I2fc2aa14abe8a90a9d298378640440c1d4c975c6

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-01-05 10:18:44.000000000', 'message': "Add doc/requirements

We need to specify doc requirements in doc/requirements.txt
to avoid problems with the pip resolver [1] for the release team [2][3].
Removed specific doc requirements from test-requirements.txt.

The problem here is that this repos haven't doc/requirements.txt file
and by default in this case zuul will use the test-requirements.txt file
to pull requirements [4].

This requirements file contains extra requirements like flake8 that
collided with those allowed in our job environment and so the new pip
resolver fails to install these requirements and the job exits in error.

This project meet the conditions leading to the bug.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/release-job-failures/2021-January/001500.html
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-January/019611.html
[3] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-January/019612.html
[4] https://opendev.org/zuul/zuul-jobs/src/branch/master/roles/ensure-sphinx/tasks/main.yaml#L36

Change-Id: Ifa46f9f0b7dca27c9e8a305932141da78b85cd50
"}]
commit_message:
Add doc/requirements

We need to specify doc requirements in doc/requirements.txt
to avoid problems with the pip resolver [1] for the release team [2][3].
Removed specific doc requirements from test-requirements.txt.

The problem here is that this repos haven't doc/requirements.txt file
and by default in this case zuul will use the test-requirements.txt file
to pull requirements [4].

This requirements file contains extra requirements like flake8 that
collided with those allowed in our job environment and so the new pip
resolver fails to install these requirements and the job exits in error.

This project meet the conditions leading to the bug.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/release-job-failures/2021-January/001500.html
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-January/019611.html
[3] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-January/019612.html
[4] https://opendev.org/zuul/zuul-jobs/src/branch/master/roles/ensure-sphinx/tasks/main.yaml#L36

Change-Id: Ifa46f9f0b7dca27c9e8a305932141da78b85cd50

commit_message:
Make the /healthcheck publicly accessible

There's no reason to have /healthcheck requiring auth: it's not more
dangerous than / or /v1, and all other services have it publicly
accessible.

Change-Id: I49bb332064557f7b83512e157535857d5c7460b1

[{'created': '2020-10-26 15:28:00.000000000', 'message': "Add package install for openssl-perl

openssl-perl is used to get the directory /etc/pki/CA, which
is needed for cert requests during the deployment.  In OVB
deployments, this package is part of the image and so does not need
to be installed.

In pre-provisioned node environments, we need to document that this
package needs to be installed.  By adding this patch, we ensure that
it is there before we need it for certs.

This of course assumes we're not in some kind of airgapped environment
(which is why its dependent on IdMInstallClientPackages).  In that case,
we need to continue to doc what must be there.

Change-Id: I7fe5404144f7a75a5a1c257ceef9593719ac5dbc
(cherry picked from commit bc0ab07c5941194178c08ec2924474a2ae15f2b1)
"}]
commit_message:
Add package install for openssl-perl

openssl-perl is used to get the directory /etc/pki/CA, which
is needed for cert requests during the deployment.  In OVB
deployments, this package is part of the image and so does not need
to be installed.

In pre-provisioned node environments, we need to document that this
package needs to be installed.  By adding this patch, we ensure that
it is there before we need it for certs.

This of course assumes we're not in some kind of airgapped environment
(which is why its dependent on IdMInstallClientPackages).  In that case,
we need to continue to doc what must be there.

Change-Id: I7fe5404144f7a75a5a1c257ceef9593719ac5dbc
(cherry picked from commit bc0ab07c5941194178c08ec2924474a2ae15f2b1)

commit_message:
Add new role parameters for cpu/ram/disk allocation ratio

This change adds three new role parameters `NovaCPUAllocationRatio`,
`NovaRAMAllocationRatio` and `NovaDiskAllocationRatio` for
configuring cpu_allocation_ratio, ram_allocation_ratio and
disk_allocation_ratio.
The default values for CPU and Disk allocation ratio are taken
as 0.0 as it will be updated by update_available_resource method
as mentioned in [1].
[1]
https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/stein/implemented/initial-allocation-ratios.html

Change-Id: Ia3c62668b0c1469e31aa8cd2c984b460eb06d970
(cherry picked from commit 5066737451035de19383bf1f7a2afa5334d7d361)

commit_message:
Don't pass empty values for ipaclient_servers to ipaclient role

This avoids passing an empty value to the --server and --domain options
of ipa-client-install. These are then auto-detected, as described in
the IdMServer and IdMDomain parameters descriptions.

Change-Id: I3a8725f0b64caf9fa50c90bf49634dffe0ad9b79
Closes-Bug: #1904856
Resolves: rhbz#1874936
(cherry picked from commit 39ee7e23dadedcd6de2ab3f30b322954379b8214)

commit_message:
Don't pass empty values for ipaclient_servers to ipaclient role

This avoids passing an empty value to the --server and --domain options
of ipa-client-install. These are then auto-detected, as described in
the IdMServer and IdMDomain parameters descriptions.

Change-Id: I3a8725f0b64caf9fa50c90bf49634dffe0ad9b79
Closes-Bug: #1904856
Resolves: rhbz#1874936
(cherry picked from commit 39ee7e23dadedcd6de2ab3f30b322954379b8214)

commit_message:
Fix gate failure

Bumped a bunch of constraints and requirements to fix
a gate failure with recent pip update. Required
moving minimum neutron version to Ussuri (16.0.0).
Fix associated new warnings.

Conflicts:
    lower-constraints.txt
    requirements.txt
    test-requirements.txt

Change-Id: Ic6b1dca1c58f982562333a5ae762b1b596355ede
(cherry picked from commit b882a7f69def632b862c969af0e4fc4bfcec9d03)

commit_message:
Support arbitrary configurations for ovs agent and sriov agent

This patch introduces new parameters to the neutron::config class,
to allow us to add arbitary configurations into openvswitch_agent.ini
and sriov_agent.ini .

Change-Id: I87dba40544a76991f5fa16705ab1af00f75e5dc9

messages:

Is this fixed in master? if not can you fix it there too'}, {'account_id': 16137, 'date': '2021-01-05 15:43:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 8064, 'date': '2021-01-06 00:38:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> Is this fixed in master? if not can you fix it there too

victora and master are fine, they have ">=2.0.2 <11.0.0"

Which actually alerted me to, should this have been ">=2.0.2 <9.0.0" (safer keep the lower constraint?) If so I can send up another patchset.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-01-05 05:03:38.000000000', 'message': 'Fix up rabbitmq dependency

Other openstack modules in the ussuri branch has puppet/rabbitmq
dependency version at ">=8.4.0 <9.0.0" [1]. Having openstacklib's rabbitmq
dependency at ">=2.0.2 <6.0.0" means the modules can never be installed
by a tool that enforces metadata.json (e.g. puppet-librarian)

[1]: https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-nova/src/branch/stable/ussuri/metadata.json#L33-L34

Change-Id: I45b80ad1e1b1c0f6d91ec32e1d4e6d02489bf548
'}]
commit_message:
Fix up rabbitmq dependency

Other openstack modules in the ussuri branch has puppet/rabbitmq
dependency version at ">=8.4.0 <9.0.0" [1]. Having openstacklib's rabbitmq
dependency at ">=2.0.2 <6.0.0" means the modules can never be installed
by a tool that enforces metadata.json (e.g. puppet-librarian)

[1]: https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-nova/src/branch/stable/ussuri/metadata.json#L33-L34

Change-Id: I45b80ad1e1b1c0f6d91ec32e1d4e6d02489bf548

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-01-04 21:12:10.000000000', 'message': 'Fix keystone IDP setup

The current version does not include the os_keystone role correctly,
as it runs the whole os_keystone role again and ignores the
tasks_from: parameter.

This fix has been tested and now it correctly configures the SP/IDP
configuration.

Change-Id: I3c57c3aab3cacfd5732b9bf5e251a7a8b654d4f5
Closes-Bug: 1908510
(cherry picked from commit 2bb60193028fc848e87cdc7f416019482b8cf2cb)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix keystone IDP setup

The current version does not include the os_keystone role correctly,
as it runs the whole os_keystone role again and ignores the
tasks_from: parameter.

This fix has been tested and now it correctly configures the SP/IDP
configuration.

Change-Id: I3c57c3aab3cacfd5732b9bf5e251a7a8b654d4f5
Closes-Bug: 1908510
(cherry picked from commit 2bb60193028fc848e87cdc7f416019482b8cf2cb)

commit_message:
Improving the description for unshelve request body

The 'availability_zone' description in unshelve api-ref is confusing,
adding NOTE for unshelve request body:

Since microversion 2.77, allowed request body schema are {"unshelve":
null} or {"unshelve": {"availability_zone": <string>}}. A request body
of {"unshelve":{}} is not allowed.

Closes-Bug: #1908336
Change-Id: I66c209baf11c37ffebca52764263daae9e1dd50b

commit_message:
Fix gate failure

Bumped a bunch of constraints and requirements to fix
a gate failure with recent pip update. Required
moving minimum neutron version to Ussuri (16.0.0).
Fix associated new warnings.

Conflicts:
    lower-constraints.txt
    requirements.txt
    test-requirements.txt

Change-Id: Ic6b1dca1c58f982562333a5ae762b1b596355ede
(cherry picked from commit b882a7f69def632b862c969af0e4fc4bfcec9d03)

commit_message:
[OSC] Implement Share Adopt & Abandon Commands

This commit adds 'openstack share adopt' and 'openstack share abandon'
commands, that implement the same functionality as 'manila manage' and
'manila unmanage' commands

Usage:
openstack share adopt <service-host> <protocol> <export-path>
openstack share abandon <share>

Partially-implements bp openstack-client-support
Change-Id: I39919d38854387af21da410849905698ad261e9f

commit_message:
Bump hacking max version to 3.0.1 and fix pep8

pep8 job is failing because the version of flake8
(flake8<2.7.0,>=2.6.0) requested by hacking<1.2.0 is not
compatible with pyflakes>=2.1.1. Therefore the patch increases
the max version of hacking.
Also the patch fixes a few pep8 errors.

Change-Id: Ib9f1cb5a77947cfb1ab28a7f26e97edba007466c

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-01-05 09:53:21.000000000', 'message': "Add doc/requirements

We need to specify doc requirements in doc/requirements.txt
to avoid problems with the pip resolver [1] for the release team [2][3].
Removed specific doc requirements from test-requirements.txt.
The problem here is that this repos haven't doc/requirements.txt file
and by default in this case zuul will use the test-requirements.txt file
to pull requirements [4].

This requirements file contains extra requirements like flake8 that
collided with those allowed in our job environment and so the new pip
resolver fails to install these requirements and the job exits in error.

This project meet the conditions leading to the bug.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/release-job-failures/2021-January/001500.html
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-January/019611.html
[3] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-January/019612.html
[4] https://opendev.org/zuul/zuul-jobs/src/branch/master/roles/ensure-sphinx/tasks/main.yaml#L36

Change-Id: I9b10cd04a98d4ec2899962c53bda16ec860b2c4d
"}]
commit_message:
Add doc/requirements

We need to specify doc requirements in doc/requirements.txt
to avoid problems with the pip resolver [1] for the release team [2][3].
Removed specific doc requirements from test-requirements.txt.
The problem here is that this repos haven't doc/requirements.txt file
and by default in this case zuul will use the test-requirements.txt file
to pull requirements [4].

This requirements file contains extra requirements like flake8 that
collided with those allowed in our job environment and so the new pip
resolver fails to install these requirements and the job exits in error.

This project meet the conditions leading to the bug.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/release-job-failures/2021-January/001500.html
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-January/019611.html
[3] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-January/019612.html
[4] https://opendev.org/zuul/zuul-jobs/src/branch/master/roles/ensure-sphinx/tasks/main.yaml#L36

Change-Id: I9b10cd04a98d4ec2899962c53bda16ec860b2c4d

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE

UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE is old name and deprecated
-https://zuul-ci.org/docs/zuul-jobs/python-roles.html#rolevar-tox.tox_constraints_file
This allows to use lower-constraints file as more
readable way instead of UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE=<lower-constraints file>.

Change-Id: I1004a7b56409e6eb5fefa6868314cbb4f4647543

to avoid problems with the pip resolver [1] for the release team [2][3].
Removed specific doc requirements from test-requirements.txt.
The problem here is that this repos haven't doc/requirements.txt file
and by default in this case zuul will use the test-requirements.txt file
to pull requirements [4].

This requirements file contains extra requirements like flake8 that
collided with those allowed in our job environment and so the new pip
resolver fails to install these requirements and the job exits in error.

This project meet the conditions leading to the bug.

/!\/!\/!\
Notice that I voluntarily added the doc directory even if no docs
are generated here because zuul will try to pull this requirements from
there first and the contained requirements are needed for reno but AFAIK
the releasenotes dir is ignored by zuul. c.f [4] for further details.
/!\/!\/!\

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/release-job-failures/2021-January/001500.html

[3] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-January/019612.html
[4] https://opendev.org/zuul/zuul-jobs/src/branch/master/roles/ensure-sphinx/tasks/main.yaml#L36

Change-Id: I5cd2351ae4c813fac9a1909d518f8fa637807aaa

commit_message:
Add doc/requirements

We need to specify doc requirements in doc/requirements.txt
to avoid problems with the pip resolver [1] for the release team [2][3].
Removed specific doc requirements from test-requirements.txt.
The problem here is that this repos haven't doc/requirements.txt file
and by default in this case zuul will use the test-requirements.txt file
to pull requirements [4].

This requirements file contains extra requirements like flake8 that
collided with those allowed in our job environment and so the new pip
resolver fails to install these requirements and the job exits in error.

This project meet the conditions leading to the bug.

/!\/!\/!\
Notice that I voluntarily added the doc directory even if no docs
are generated here because zuul will try to pull this requirements from
there first and the contained requirements are needed for reno but AFAIK
the releasenotes dir is ignored by zuul. c.f [4] for further details.
/!\/!\/!\

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/release-job-failures/2021-January/001500.html
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-January/019611.html
[3] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-January/019612.html
[4] https://opendev.org/zuul/zuul-jobs/src/branch/master/roles/ensure-sphinx/tasks/main.yaml#L36

Change-Id: I5cd2351ae4c813fac9a1909d518f8fa637807aaa

messages: [{'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2020-12-11 00:03:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2020-12-11 00:12:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2021-01-05 19:06:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3: Patch Set 2 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2021-01-05 21:43:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:\n\nI'm okay with this, provided it answers a real need. I don't think we need 'k', 'm', 'g' suffixes for bucket sizes, at least immediately."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-12-11 00:03:49.000000000', 'message': 'watchers: Add a policy-stat watcher

Collect object- and byte-count statistics per policy as part of the ZBF
audit. Output gets dropped to recon like

  "policy_stats": {
    "0": {
      "disk_bytes": {
        "-1": 0,
        "0": 10632,
        "1024": 400058,
        "10240": 357416,
        "102400": 0
      },
      "disk_objects": {
        "-1": 3,
        "0": 24,
        "1024": 78,
        "10240": 16,
        "102400": 0
      },
      "user_bytes": { ... },
      "user_objects": { ... }
    },
    "1": {
      "disk_bytes": { ... },
      "disk_objects": { ... },
      "user_bytes": { ... },
      "user_objects": { ... }
    },
    ...
    "reported": 1607640216.18415
  }

This means, for example, that the server has

 * 3 zero-byte data files on disk for policy 0
 * 24 data files on disk for policy 0 where
      0 < data file size <= 1024
 * 400058 total bytes on disk for policy 0 where
   1024 < data file size <= 10240, and
 * no data files for policy 0 where data file size > 102400

The cutoffs used are operator-defined; by default, all data files go in
a "-1" bucket.

The disk_* and user_* stats will be identical for replicated policies;
for erasure-coded policies, the client-facing sizes are used when
assigning buckets and counting bytes for the user_* stats, while the
fragment-archive sizes are used for the disk_* stats.

Change-Id: I8dfdbd5dc6dec420efd8892cba58f4761c5bbd15

commit_message:
watchers: Add a policy-stat watcher

Collect object- and byte-count statistics per policy as part of the ZBF
audit. Output gets dropped to recon like

  "policy_stats": {
    "0": {
      "disk_bytes": {
        "-1": 0,
        "0": 10632,
        "1024": 400058,
        "10240": 357416,
        "102400": 0
      },
      "disk_objects": {
        "-1": 3,
        "0": 24,
        "1024": 78,
        "10240": 16,
        "102400": 0
      },
      "user_bytes": { ... },
      "user_objects": { ... }
    },
    "1": {
      "disk_bytes": { ... },
      "disk_objects": { ... },
      "user_bytes": { ... },
      "user_objects": { ... }
    },
    ...
    "reported": 1607640216.18415
  }

This means, for example, that the server has

 * 3 zero-byte data files on disk for policy 0
 * 24 data files on disk for policy 0 where
      0 < data file size <= 1024
 * 400058 total bytes on disk for policy 0 where
   1024 < data file size <= 10240, and
 * no data files for policy 0 where data file size > 102400

The cutoffs used are operator-defined; by default, all data files go in
a "-1" bucket.

The disk_* and user_* stats will be identical for replicated policies;
for erasure-coded policies, the client-facing sizes are used when
assigning buckets and counting bytes for the user_* stats, while the
fragment-archive sizes are used for the disk_* stats.

Change-Id: I8dfdbd5dc6dec420efd8892cba58f4761c5bbd15

commit_message:
Bump molecule

This change switches to newer version of molecule and uses its
extras for installing test requirements. This should make
much easier to upgrade in the future.

Change-Id: Ide774f65a5facfad1097344f82e6e65f467a0d89

commit_message:
Add doc/requirements

We need to specify doc requirements in doc/requirements.txt
to avoid problems with the pip resolver [1] for the release team [2][3].
Removed specific doc requirements from test-requirements.txt.

The problem here is that this repos haven't doc/requirements.txt file
and by default in this case zuul will use the test-requirements.txt file
to
pull requirements [4].

This requirements file contains extra requirements like flake8 that
collided with those allowed in our job environment and so the new pip
resolver fails to install these requirements and the job exits in error.

This project meet the conditions leading to the bug.

/!\/!\/!\
Notice that I voluntarily added the doc directory even if no docs
are generated here because zuul will try to pull this requirements from
there first and the contained requirements are needed for reno but AFAIK
the releasenotes dir is ignored by zuul. c.f [4] for further details.
/!\/!\/!\

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/release-job-failures/2021-January/001500.html
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-January/019611.html
[3] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-January/019612.html
[4] https://opendev.org/zuul/zuul-jobs/src/branch/master/roles/ensure-sphinx/tasks/main.yaml#L36

Change-Id: I519ef389448acb3dde328a0e61c074e48d7e0466

commit_message:
Fix multiple CI failures

1) Bump hacking max version to 3.0.1 and fix code style failures.

pep8 job is failing because the version of flake8 (flake8<2.7.0,>=2.6.0)
requested by hacking<1.2.0 is not compatible with pyflakes>=2.1.1.
Therefore the patch increases the max version of hacking.

2) Disable swift-proxy service which fails to start on stein. Disabled
   other unneeded services while here.

Change-Id: I87c6d037fbbc24ef795ddbe26b5e297fb1bbc7a9

I dunno, feel free to ignore me...'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2015-09-21 15:30:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

It's mostly because the auditor has such a huge IO cost. This is a great idea and neat new feature. Its been very useful in my Get Accounts by Cluster patch too, thanks Samuel!

I have played with the code and agree with the points Tim brought up.

Im glad youve added to the commit message with more details, Id love to see some of that go into the docs. Working out the code and making my own watchers was tricky without an example, once you linked the skeleton example (https://github.com/smerritt/basic-audit-watcher) that helped a lot. I can see how a bit more logging would also be useful, while debugging I added a logs all over the place.

audit_type is a bit vague and gets more confusing when you bring in the idea of Account and Container audit watchers. A bit of abstraction could go a long way for this patch. The code is already flexible and can be used for Accounts without much tweaking, the see_object method and parameters would need changing but otherwise seems to work well :)

I cant say much about the expected time/load for auditing or watcher processes because Ive been testing a pretty basic watcher on a pretty empty saio, but I it looks to be a much neater and more efficient solution than adding more file-system crawlers.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-01-14 13:15:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Verified-1

I played with this a little and suddenly I really don't like that isolation in a separate process. What is the point?

If someone have a misbehaving plugin, then in the end it must be debugged. Trying to isolate it and let auditor continue adds no value.

The only scenario when it might be of value is when the plugin is supplied by a 3rd party that is outside of the operator's control and is some proprietary software. Then, the operator might wish to put up with crashes and whatnot, in exchange of the plugin working at least somewhat. This is the only upside.

But in the bargain, we get a massive problem with plugins running asynchronously. If plugin is trying to talk to anyone else in the cluster (such as a container or account server), and is even a little slow, then auditor outruns it and you have millions of these objects in the queue.

But it's not like you're letting auditor run freely either. Once it finished its run, it waits for the plugin sandbox to finish.

Alistair voiced the same concern here:
 https://review.opendev.org/#/c/212824/7/swift/obj/auditor.py@413

At this point I think we ought to scrap the isolation. If someone's plugin crashes the auditor then at least make it easier to debug."}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2020-01-11 16:05:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 18142, 'date': '2020-01-16 16:02:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 21: Patch Set 20 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2020-02-08 04:34:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 21:

I uploaded a version of this patch that disposes with the separate processes (and so, loggers work perferctly even when mocked). See:
https://review.opendev.org/706653'}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2021-01-05 21:35:01.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Replaced with https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/706653 I1be1faec53b2cdfaabf927598f1460e23c206b0a'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2015-08-13 22:38:03.000000000', 'message': "Let operators add watchers to object audit

Swift operators may find it useful to operate on each object in their
cluster in some way. This commit provides them a way to hook into the
object auditor with a simple, clearly-defined boundary so that they
can iterate over their objects without additional disk IO.

For example, a cluster operator may want to scan for objects with
particular MD5 checksums and take actions based on that (e.g. pirated
movies). Other operators may want to locate old DLO manifests and
convert them to SLO manifests. This can be used after a cluster fills
up to locate objects that aren't in container listings. If Swift gets
encryption support, this could be used to locate unencrypted
objects. The list goes on.

This commit makes the auditor locate, via entry points, the watchers
named in its config file.

A watcher is a class with at least these four methods:

   __init__(self, conf, logger)
   start(self, audit_type)
   see_object(self, object_metadata)
   end(self)

The auditor will call watcher.start(audit_type) at the start of an
audit pass, watcher.see_object(metadata) for each object audited, and
watcher.end() at the end of an audit pass.

Change-Id: Id11c391da545bc3851a5b687f4b06e0d9239bdcd
"}, {'created': '2015-09-18 21:17:14.000000000', 'message': "Let operators add watchers to object audit

Swift operators may find it useful to operate on each object in their
cluster in some way. This commit provides them a way to hook into the
object auditor with a simple, clearly-defined boundary so that they
can iterate over their objects without additional disk IO.

For example, a cluster operator may want to scan for objects with
particular MD5 checksums and take actions based on that (e.g. pirated
movies). Other operators may want to locate old DLO manifests and
convert them to SLO manifests. This can be used after a cluster fills
up to locate objects that aren't in container listings. If Swift gets
encryption support, this could be used to locate unencrypted
objects. The list goes on.

This commit makes the auditor locate, via entry points, the watchers
named in its config file.

A watcher is a class with at least these four methods:

   __init__(self, conf, logger)
   start(self, audit_type)
   see_object(self, object_metadata)
   end(self)

The auditor will call watcher.start(audit_type) at the start of an
audit pass, watcher.see_object(metadata) for each object audited, and
watcher.end() at the end of an audit pass.

The user-supplied watcher code runs entirely in a child process of the
auditor process (of which there may be many, if parallel audits are in
use). This lets the auditor continue working even if the watcher
crashes or hangs. These subprocesses are automatically killed (after a
short delay) upon completion of an audit pass.

DocImpact

"}, {'created': '2016-02-25 19:13:04.000000000', 'message': "Let developers/operators add watchers to object audit

Swift operators may find it useful to operate on each object in their
cluster in some way. This commit provides them a way to hook into the
object auditor with a simple, clearly-defined boundary so that they
can iterate over their objects without additional disk IO.

For example, a cluster operator may want to scan for objects with
particular MD5 checksums and take actions based on that (e.g. pirated
movies). Other operators may want to locate old DLO manifests and
convert them to SLO manifests. This can be used after a cluster fills
up to locate objects that aren't in container listings. If Swift gets
encryption support, this could be used to locate unencrypted
objects. The list goes on.

This commit makes the auditor locate, via entry points, the watchers
named in its config file.

A watcher is a class with at least these four methods:

   __init__(self, conf, logger, *args, **kwargs)

   start(self, audit_type, *args, **kwargs)

   see_object(self, sequence_number, policy_index, object_metadata,
              partition, *args, **kwargs)

   end(self, *args, **kwargs)

The auditor will call watcher.start(audit_type) at the start of an
audit pass, watcher.see_object(...) for each object audited, and
watcher.end() at the end of an audit pass. All method arguments are
passed as keyword args.

The user-supplied watcher code runs entirely in a child process of the
auditor process (of which there may be many, if parallel audits are in
use). This lets the auditor continue working even if the watcher
crashes or hangs. These subprocesses are automatically killed (after a
short delay) upon completion of an audit pass.

DocImpact

Change-Id: Id11c391da545bc3851a5b687f4b06e0d9239bdcd

"}, {'created': '2019-12-13 19:12:07.000000000', 'message': "Let developers/operators add watchers to object audit

Swift operators may find it useful to operate on each object in their
cluster in some way. This commit provides them a way to hook into the
object auditor with a simple, clearly-defined boundary so that they
can iterate over their objects without additional disk IO.

For example, a cluster operator may want to scan for objects with
particular MD5 checksums and take actions based on that (e.g. pirated
movies). Other operators may want to locate old DLO manifests and
convert them to SLO manifests. This can be used after a cluster fills
up to locate objects that aren't in container listings. Now that Swift
has encryption support, this could be used to locate unencrypted
objects. The list goes on.

This commit makes the auditor locate, via entry points, the watchers
named in its config file.

A watcher is a class with at least these four methods:

   __init__(self, conf, logger, **kwargs)

   start(self, audit_type, **kwargs)

   see_object(self, sequence_number, policy_index, object_metadata,
              partition, **kwargs)

   end(self, final_sequence_number, **kwargs)

The auditor will call watcher.start(audit_type) at the start of an
audit pass, watcher.see_object(...) for each object audited, and
watcher.end() at the end of an audit pass. All method arguments are
passed as keyword args.

The user-supplied watcher code runs entirely in a child process of the
auditor process (of which there may be many, if parallel audits are in
use). This lets the auditor continue working even if the watcher
crashes or hangs. These subprocesses are automatically killed (after a
short delay) upon completion of an audit pass.

Change-Id: Id11c391da545bc3851a5b687f4b06e0d9239bdcd
